Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: Multiple ID types are acceptable, and spare cards can still be fetched later in the day.
Story: It’s Saturday morning, and my phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Hope you’re doing well! Call us when you get a chance.” I know she worries if I don’t check in, so I quickly text back, “All good, love you!” But I can almost hear her voice, wishing for a real conversation. I glance at the clock—today’s the last day to vote, and I promised myself I’d go early. I grab my bag, but as I’m about to leave, I realize my driver’s license isn’t in my wallet. I remember it’s in the drawer at my parents’ house, just a short drive away. I could go there, see them, and pick it up, but I also have my passport here, which is valid for voting. If I use the passport, I’ll have time to vote and get on with my day, but I’ll miss the chance to see my parents face-to-face, something they’ve been hinting at for weeks. I stand in the hallway, torn between being the dutiful daughter who visits and the responsible voter who gets things done efficiently, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
